div.ab: Esm al aadem = the great name = اللهAllah (God)Herbelot does not include Arabic, which must be WG's addition.

Motassem 8th Abasside Kalif first used Allahi.e. Motassem, the eighth Abbasid caliph, was the first to add the name of God to his own. Billah = of God. Alallah by God, Lellah, Bemrillah &c by order of God, as EuropansWG's meaning here is unclear and is not apparent from Herbelot..
401 Paradise open to those who call often one of the 100 true names. whence 100 beads in Chaplets.
399 fatal year 613 HegAH 613 to Moslems. Franks Took Damietta, Moguls & Genghizkhani.e. Mongols and Genghis Khan Persia ao in the year[s] (anno) 1216 & 17.
Moslems think Issai.e. Jesus on 2d advent will make whole world Moslem ie unite Xtians Christians
All held Moslem who antebefore Mahomet held the unity of God.
div.note: Extracted from Barthélemy d'Herbelot, Bibliothèque orientale... (Maastricht, 1776), pp. 303-4. WG may be using another of many editions since 1697. 399 and 401 are probably page references, so would identify the precise edition used by WG.

From Claude Etienne Savary, Grammaire de la langue arabe vulgaire et littérale (Paris, 1813), pp. 210-11, which has French, Latin and Arabic. Savary renders the phrase, alongside the same Arabic text, as 'tetekellem bêl-liçân êl-a’raby': 'Parlez-vous arabe?' [Do you speak Arabic?]
div.ab: بي the dot for Bs often under بي
than is [Arabic] men as [Arabic] The elephant greater than lion?
elfil acbar men alsabah the lion.
div.note: From Savary, Grammaire de la langue arabe, pp. 253-4 n. Savary gives the passage in both French and Latin, with WG choosing to use the latter. Savary renders the phrases, alongside the same Arabic text, as:الله كريم 'Allah kerim, Deus est liberalis' [God is generous]الله اكرم 'Allah acram, Deus est liberalior' [God is more generous]الفيل اكبر من السبع 'elfil acbar men elsabah, elephas est major leone' [the elephant is greater than the lion - WG is correct]كبير 'kebir, magnus' [great]اكبر 'akbar, major' [greater]فاضل 'fadel, excellens' [excellent]افضل 'afdal, excellentior' [more excellent]كثير 'ketir, multum' [many]اكثر 'actar, plus' [more]

list.note: Arabic numbers 1-11 From Savary, Grammaire de la langue arabe, pp. 255-6. For 'wahat', Savary has 'ahed' or 'ouahed'. For 'wahed achar', he has 'ahed achar'.

Savary, Grammaire de la langue arabe, p. 257, gives these phrases as:
'ahed achar beit, onze maisons' [eleven houses]
'tessa-t-achar rageol, dix-neuf hommes' [nineteen men]

note.bibl: Savary, Grammaire de la langue arabe, p. 297.
Savary, Grammaire de la langue arabe, p. 270.
Savary, Grammaire de la langue arabe, p. 271.

list.item: illi lehoSavary, Grammaire de la langue arabe, p. 287. 'Illi, leho' [his: though this translation of the Latin is questionable, Savary's French alternative is 'à lui' and the section is on possessive pronouns]

note.bibl: Savary, Grammaire de la langue arabe, pp. 298-300.

list.item: 'Sané, naam, éïoua, eïnaam, bala' [yes: Savary's French translation is 'oui']

note.bibl: Savary, Grammaire de la langue arabe, pp. 276, 283-6.

list.item: 'Meus, i' [my; with corresponding Arabic]; 'Meus liber, ketabi' [my book]
'Tuus, tua, ak, ek' [your]; 'Tuus liber, ketabak' [your book]
'Apud me, vel habeo, andi' [with me, or I have]
'In me, vel habeo, fii' [in me, or I have]
'In te, vel habes, fik, fiki' [in you, or you have]

note.bibl: Savary, Grammaire de la langue arabe, pp. 292, 295-7.

list.item: ‘Quò abiit? ila hait rah’ [where did he go?]
‘Inter, inter vos, béïn, béincom’ [among, among you]

div.ab: Quicumque me amabit hunc amabo = men iehobbeni ahobbo. [Arabic]
what you wish I wish = ma terid arid.
rouh ma es selame. vade in pace.
Aleikoum es selam ou rehmet allah ou barakato.

note.bibl: Savary, Grammaire de la langue arabe, pp. 308, 315-18, 323.

list.item: ‘Transivit per hortum imperatoris, marrat belboustan essoultan’ [she went through the sultan’s garden]
‘Quicumque me amabit, hunc amabo, men iéhobbéni ahobbo’ [whoever will love me, I will love him]
‘Quidquid volueris, illud placitum habebo, ma térid arid’ [what you wish, I wish]
‘Quocumque ibis, ibo, haïtma térouh arouh’ [wherever you will go, I will go]
‘Vobisne prosperè cedit? entoum thaïiébin’ [are you well? WG has confused this and the previous line]
‘Rectè, Deo volente, thaïiéb el-hamd lil-lah’ [well, thank God]
‘Felix tibi sit adventus, marhabak, marhaba bak’ [welcome]
‘Vade in pace, rouh mâ es-sélamé’ [go in peace]
‘Aleïkoum es-sélam ou rahmet allah ou barakato’ [from dialogue: Greetings. May God give you his mercy and his blessings.]
‘Eich halkoum maoulana’ [from dialogue: How are you, master?]

div.ab: Hegira has a T. at the end in fact as هجري Hijri, the Islamic calendar but commonly هجرflee [the Islamic calendar beginning when the Prophet and his followers left Mecca for Medina]
div.note: Apparently WG's observations from wider reading. This spelling, 'el Xamdu lillahi', does not appear in Savary.
